name: Batagor Bandung (Indonesian Fried Tofu)
author: Mekmolek
summary: This is a very popular street food found around the Sunda region of Western Java. Batagor is an acronym for Bakso Tahu Goreng (Fried Tofu Balls) though it's not really a ball, but more of a triangle shape. The tofu is stuffed with a mixture of savory ground meat, steamed, and then coated with batter and fried; it is served with a spicy sweet chile-peanut sauce.
ingredients: ½ cup prawns - peeled, deveined, and minced
salt and ground white pepper to taste
¼ cup coarsely chopped dry roasted peanuts
1  fresh red chile pepper, finely chopped
directions: Slice each tofu square diagonally to make 8 triangles
Make a cut into the base of each tofu triangle and scoop out enough of tofu to create a pocket
Combine scooped-out tofu pieces, prawns, egg, ground chicken, green onion, cornstarch, sesame oil, salt, and pepper in a bowl for the filling
Carefully stuff filling back into the tofu triangles; the filling will bulge out
Place a steamer insert into a saucepan and fill with water to just below the bottom of the steamer
Add stuffed tofu triangles, cover, and steam for 20 minutes
Mix egg and flour in a bowl
Whisk in enough water to give batter a medium-thin consistency
Combine water, peanuts, red chile pepper, garlic, vinegar, salt, and sugar in a bowl
Stir until salt and sugar have dissolved and set sauce aside
Remove cooked tofu triangles from the steamer
Heat oil in a wok until hot
Dip triangles into the batter and slowly lower into the hot oil
Fry in batches until golden brown and the batter is cooked through, about 5 minutes
Serve hot with the peanut sauce
